items.title: Hacker
items.description: The Hacker ethos consists of making software work, but allowing for short cuts.

items.title: Kanban
items.description:
Kanban development utilizes visual cards that move between columns as work complete certain stages. 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanban

items.title: Waterfall
items.description:
Waterfall is based on extensive planning and consists of distinct phases which flow after each other.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waterfall_model

items.title: Agile
items.description:
Agile focuses on adapting to changes during a projects life cycle using iterative development.

Scrum implements agile.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agile_software_development

items.title: OKR
items.description:
OKR is a framework of defining and tracking objectives and their outcomes.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OKR

items.title: MVP
items.description: Minimal Viable Product (MVP) is focused on get early customer feedback by releasing early, and gathering feedback for the following product iteratives.

states.label: Innovation trigger
states.description: A potential technology breakthrough kicks things off.

states.label: Peak expectation
states.description: Early publicity produces a number of success stories â€” often accompanied by scores of failures.

states.label: Disillusionment
states.description: Interest wanes as experiments and implementations fail to deliver. Producers of the technology shake out or fail.

states.label: Enlightenment
states.description: More instances of how the technology can benefit the market start to crystallize.

states.label: Productivity plateau
states.description: Mainstream adoption starts to take off. The technology's broad market applicability and relevance are clearly paying off.
